channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Taliban Attack in Kabul Tests Afghan Forces
item.description: The attackers set off a large explosion followed by numerous smaller blasts, sending United Nations and international agency workers into bomb shelters.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and SHARIFULLAH SAHAK
item.media:description: A wounded Afghan police officer is carried away from the scene in Kabul.

item.title: Lens Blog: Angelos Tzortzinis's Photos of Growing Desperation in Greece
item.description: The perils of a drawn-out debt crisis are imprinted on Greece’s younger population, whose unemployment numbers are soaring, and who are selling their bodies for money and turning to a dangerous, cheap new street drug for escape.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Ending Mideast Visit, Kerry Calls for Leadership
item.description: After meetings with Israeli and Palestinian officials, Secretary of State John Kerry urged them to “demonstrate leadership” to find a way back to direct peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Earthquake in Russia’s Far East Prompts Evacuations
item.description: An 8.3-magnitude quake off the Kamchatka Peninsula sent tremors that prompted evacuations as far away as Moscow, but there were no injuries.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Museums Move to Return Human Remains to Indigenous Peoples
item.description: Institutions like the Museum of Medical History in Berlin are responding to increasing claims to return bones and other human artifacts in their collections to indigenous peoples.
item.category: Museum of Medical History in Berlin
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Schnalke, the director of the Museum of Medical History in Berlin, in one of the museum's exhibition rooms.

item.title: 2 on Diverted Pakistani Plane Made Threats They Called Jokes
item.description: British fighter jets were scrambled after the pilot of the Pakistani flight reported the threat. The two men were arrested after the plane landed.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Chris Radburn/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: More than 300 passengers were forced to disembark from Pakistan International Airlines flight number PK709 flying from Lahore to Manchester on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 24
item.description: A statue of Lord Buddha being cleaned on the eve of the Buddhist festival of Wesak.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A statue of Lord Buddha in Agartala, Tripura, being cleaned on the eve of Wesak, a Buddhist festival that commemorates the birth of Gautam Buddha.

item.title: Russia Says Syria Will Attend Geneva Peace Talks
item.description: The United States and Russia agreed this month to pull together the peace conference, with Russia responsible for bringing the government of Bashar al-Assad to the table.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: The Caucus: Obama Defies Critics With State Dept. Choice
item.description: President Obama’s choice for assistant secretary for European and Eurasian affairs is Victoria Nuland, who was involved in editing controversial talking points about the attack last year in Benghazi, Libya.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Beijing Plans to Reduce the State’s Role in the Economy
item.description: After years of relying on state spending to supercharge growth, China’s new prime minister, Li Keqiang, said the government would seek to unleash the nation’s creative energies.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Workers at a construction site of a residential project in Rizhao, China. Beijing has signaled that, even though the economy is weakening, there is unlikely to be a major government stimulus package this year.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: America’s Profligate Ways With Water
item.description: As drought increases and the climate changes, the prosperous ‘civilized’ world may end up living like the Bedouins, only less well.
item.dc:creator: By MORT ROSENBLUM

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Pictures Tell the Story of Portuguese in France
item.description: An exhibition in Paris shows 20 years of work by a Haitian photojournalist who documented Portuguese immigrants as they made their way north.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER MARC
item.media:description: Gérald Bloncourt's photograph of a Portuguese girl in a slum outside Paris in 1969.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Riots Dent Image of Sweden’s Classless Social Model
item.description: Sweden and its Scandinavian neighbors are proud of their tradition of tolerance, prosperity and tranquillity. But almost a week of rioting in Stockholm suburbs populated predominantly by immigrants is threatening that image.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Firemen extinguish a row of burning cars in the suburb of Rinkeby, a suburb of Stockholm, on May 23. Youths have been rioting all week.

item.title: China Tells North Korea to Return to Nuclear Talks
item.description: The Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, struck a stern tone as he called for the denuclearization of the Korean peninsula, according to a state-run Chinese news agency.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, right, greets North Korean envoy, Vice Marshal Choe, in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: Unique ID Program Introduces Instant Verification Services
item.description: Three new schemes were introduced Friday as part of the government’s unique identification program.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A woman undergoing an eye scan as part of the Unique Identification Database enrollment process in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, on Feb. 13.

item.title: Chief of Austrian Bank Offers to Resign
item.description: Herbert Steptic, the chief executive of Raiffeisen Bank International, is facing scrutiny of his personal investments in Asian real estate.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA WERDIGIER
item.media:description: Herbert Stepic, chief executive of Raiffeisen Bank International, which operates in 17 markets in Central and Eastern Europe.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The Art Hong Kong Really Loves: ‘Rubber Duck’
item.description: Collectors may be flocking to Art Basel Hong Kong, but the biggest crowd-pleaser is an enormous rubber duck.
item.dc:creator: By JOYCE LAU
item.media:description: The Dutch artist Florentijin Hofman's giant rubber duck in Victoria Harbor.

item.title: Britain to Debate New Security Powers After Attack
item.description: With Britain still reeling with shock at the brutality and chilling indifference of the perpetrators, officials confirmed that both suspects had been known to security agents.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: Flowers lay in the southeast London neighborhood of Woolwich on Thursday, where a British soldier, Lee Rigby, 25, was killed by two men wielding cleavers.

item.title: ‘Comfort Women’ Cancel Meeting With Japanese Mayor
item.description: The South Korean women were concerned that Mayor Toru Hashimoto of Osaka, who made provocative comments defending World War II brothels, was seeking to repair his image.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Toru Hashimoto, the mayor of Osaka, spoke to the press on Friday.

item.title: Letter from Europe: Qatari Hopes for Paris Saint-Germain Meet Reality
item.description: It's been a tough week for the Gulf kingdom investors who, since they bought the team in June 2011, have lavished millions on the club and its players.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 24
item.description: Obama on drone strikes and Guantánamo Bay; Swiss bank scrutiny; English at French universities; olive oil rules; Myanmar and Orwell; odds at Cannes; and the soccer song.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: President Obama spoke at the National Defense University.

item.title: India Ink: Ponzi Scheme Threatens ‘Clean’ Image of Mamata Banerjee
item.description: Ms. Banerjee, who has been projected as the “symbol of honesty” in West Bengal, is fighting hard to restore voters’ confidence.
item.dc:creator: By SWATI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee during a news conference in Kolkata, West Bengal, on Sept. 18, 2012.

item.title: 5 Climbers Feared Dead on Himalayan Peak
item.description: A noted Hungarian climber near his goal of scaling the world’s 14 highest peaks is missing along with four others.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Questions in London Killing Echo Boston Bombing
item.description: After the brutal daylight murder of an off-duty soldier in a London suburb, questions about homegrown threats and copycats resonate in the British capital, as calm prevails.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Women laid flowers on Thursday at the scene of the London murder.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The Future of High-Tech Immigrants to the U.S.
item.description: Foreign graduate students at U.C. Berkeley reflect on how immigration reform could make it easier for highly skilled workers to stay in the United States. Or encourage them to return home.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
